column10: b'b" Ok
column11: I think I\'ve found the issue.In url  you compare the stored id with the id the client requests. By handling the result with >= 0
column12: ids that are bigger than the stored _lastMessageId are recognized as if the client had the latest message.There should be a seperate if that checks for bigger ids and responds with the stored _lastMessageId. I have implemented this check already and it fixes the issue in my tests. Will provide a pull request later on so you can have a look at it ;-)"'

b"b' Ability to configure various client timeouts'"
b"b' Currently many timeouts are hard coded and it would be beneficial to be able to change the timeouts for operation in specific environments. For example
column11: when using the library over a cell network
column12: latency times may require longer timeouts on specific transports for them to successfully negotiate. I have added them to the connections config so that they can be tweaked here 1ad5bd39ec5c64143782783033147b6735fe1889 .'"

column10: b'b" Why do you need times to be specific per transport? Can\'t we just make all 3000 (like I see in your change) and not have so many knobs?"'
b'b" For example
column11: you may have a network proxy device (such as a load balancer)  that will only negotiage SSE in a given timeframe. We will then have the option to teak the timeout to make it work and NO always fail over to long polling. This is just an example
column12: but my experience with network software is that the enviroments are too diverse to have a \'one size fit\'s all\'. IMO
column13: if you don\'t add this now
column14: you will be adding it later :)  "'

column10: b'b" One size fits all is what I\'d recommend until it doesn\'t work anymore. Plus if it doesn\'t work for you change the javascript. The overall change is fine tho."'
b"b' Agreed
column11: the more knobs
column12: the more to test
column13: the more to document and the more for developers to screw .'"

column10: b'b" Thats ok we\'ll deal with it when it happens. Btw you can do that either way and SSE is basically the same as forever transport."'
b'b" That\'s ok ... I will work around this. Thanks"'

b'b" I don\'t really see how much difference it\'s going to make. Let\'s say you tell your customer that he needs to tweak the timeout (which I find bizarre) how bad is it that the timeout affects 3 transports rather than one? Unless I\'m missing something or we\'re misunderstanding each other."'
b"b' I think we are coming at this from two different perspectives. I guess it is bizarre that someone would want to change timeouts.'"

b'b" We have a misunderstanding. Of course it\'s sensitive to the environment and of course we\'ll let you set them per client (if you read carefully you\'ll see that I agree). I agree with the general idea but you\'re stirring up a huge discussion because I\'m saying that server sent events and forever frame should have the same timeout period.  If you look at your code change
column11: you made them both equal that\'s because they are implemented in almost exactly the same way server side and will probably behave the same way on the client.  Am I wrong?"'

column10: b"b' Yes
column11: I can agree on the SSE vs FF timeouts ... but that was not my issue and it was not how your response was perceived when I first read it.'"

column10: b'b\' Transports need to send "Keep Alives"\''
b'b\' In order to better support traversing network equipment that perform an kind of proxy function such as load balancers
column11: UTM (Unified Thread Managment)
column12: proxy servers etc
column13: a "keep alive" is required to keep the connection open. \''

column10: b"b' The current time-out mechanism makes the streaming protocols no different then long polling given the dynamics and payload. Until this issue is resolved
column11: users will likely be better off with a long polling solution.'"

column10: b'b" You can make the timeout infinite if you wanted to simulate the old behavior. We\'ll look at keep alive in the next release."'

b"b' SignalR ScaleOut'"
b"b' Dear David and Damian
column11: Great work with SignalR. I integrated 0.3.5 SignalR into a new enterprise  solution that will be hitting production in the next few weeks. Last week I downloaded the latest version 0.4.0 and upgraded my code to include groups in the method OnConnectedAsync
column12: etc. Everything was working excellent until I realized that the  project code had all been commented out and I had to remove  from my build folder to get the system working. Please could you guys answer a few questions:\\xe2\\x80\\xa2 What was wrong with the  code?\\xe2\\x80\\xa2 0.4.0  in its current state is not scalable out of the box?\\xe2\\x80\\xa2 When will you guys have a version that can scale? I don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t want to sound ungrateful as I truly think SignalR is amazing
column13: I have been able to do things I never thought possible in .NET but I can\\xe2\\x80\\x99t put the application live until there is a stable ScaleOut solution. I have been looking at other options in the mean time. The two proposed solutions are Redis and Azure. The Azure solution: url is great but due to business constants and existing infrastructure it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s not an option. The Redis solution is a bit more in in-depth to implement as I would have to extend and Send of the PersistentConnection class. We also would need to us the .NET version of Redis that states on its download page it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s not production ready. I fear my ScaleOut work would be futile if you guys are already working on a new version of where no development work will be required other than setting up the load balanced server in the server farm.  I also think you guys would do a better job of it as you have a much better understanding of how SignalR works.  Please could you give your SignalR disciples an idea of how the ScaleOut solution will work and when it will be ready to use. Thank you for your time and thank you for creating SignalR. All the best
column14: John'"

column10: b'b" Hey John
column11: SignalR 0.4 was focused on reworking the core APIs and decoupling SignalR from . The focus for the next major release is scale out and we\'re going to have a bunch of different solutions: ## Redis Redis is already started and mostly working url  You can use a service like url  to test it out if you don\'t want to host your own server. In this impl we just use redis to push messages around but not store actual data (we don\'t handle failing nodes right now). ## Azure Service Bus url  You can read more about it here url  In addition to those we\'re going to have some other ones including:Peer to peerFile system basedSql based. Hope that answers your question. We\'re aiming for release the next version in about a month."'

column11: Thanks so much for the reply. I will re-look at the Redis and Azure options and wait for the next release with great anticipation.  Keep up the good work. John'"

b"b'  The standard fix was to include a dummy iframe and set its src to an empty  file on the root of the site after say 100ms. The route for hubs have to sit under that web. I don\'t see a way to configure signalr to use any types of authentication

column12: so negotiation would work. Do you have any suggestions to solve that security problem? Thanks."'

column14: as this is handled by lower layers automatically. What were the problems you encountered with Windows Authentication?"'

column10: b"b' Resolving problem with incorrect appRelativeUrl when SignalR is using with reverse proxy'"

column11: e.g.: /. "negotiation" request returns Url: /events which will be set in appRelativeUrl and all further requests will be passed to /events instead ofr /.  The fix checks if the Url is absolute path then it uses ; otherwise the old logic is used. \''

column11: we are still seeing this issue. Whether the request for performance counter categories is done in a separate thread or not. I found this interesting stackoverflow post. The issue is really more of an environmental setup issue
column12: than a SignalR issue.  url  We have isolated the issue to PerformanceCounterCategory. It does look like the implementation is sub-optimal
column13: as it loops through EVERY performance counter to find the one you are talking about. We tried to do a () but even that hangs (was hoping to do it in .NET memory rather than differing to Win32). Two options to get around this issue:Config setting specifying where you want performance counters or not.Create performance counters when the SignalR app starts (overwrite if it already exists). Thanks
column14: Khalid'"

column10: b'b" Sub-optimal != hang forever. The latter is what is occurring and if we can avoid it by being smart (which to date we haven\'t been able to do)
column11: then I\'d prefer going with that fix. I\'m still puzzled as to why running it on another task would still hang. I attempted a fix by starting a new thread instead of a new task and aborting the thread if it failed to come back within 2 seconds. If the first one fails then none of the rest should load."'

Error log: An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host)IIS went back to normalClient were reconnected (did receive some messages)Then
column11: a few seconds later
column12: server triggered OnDisconnected()ALL reconnected clients were force-disconnected.From this point on
column13: ALL connections (new or old) will be force-disconnected. (OnDisconnected() triggered
column14: a few seconds after a new client connected).Manual IIS restart and Manual Connect at Client app was the only solution so far. '"

column10: b'b" When iis restarts
column11: the clients will reconnect for a configured timeout (40 seconds by default). It _should_ normally be enough time for IIS to restart successfully unless it\'s some kind of abnormal restart. After that timeout the disconnected event will be raised on the client. Your application needs to handle that and do something that makes sense. This is by design."'

column10: b'b" What\'s the regression here? The fact that the command was received before it needed to be? What does the server side logging look like?"'
b'b" We can\'t just remove the disconnect command. It\'s required to help ensure that the disconnect event is only raised once on the server side. With out it
column11: we would raise the disconnect event
column12: then a client could come back (reconnect) and start receiving messages again on the same connection ID. When they do actually disconnect we\'d raise the disconnect event again for the same connection ID."'

SignalR	1495	closed	3	smithkl42	2013-02-06 23:29:16	128.68		+1		b'b" Hi, David. Yes, that\'s exactly the scenario, though I\'ve waited for 5-10 minutes, and never seen fire. And I\'m using RC2. Here\'s the logs. To keep it a bit simpler, I\'ve stripped out everything that didn\'t have its source in SignalR. That\'s all. The last log entry was actually before I disconnected the network. I didn\'t see any entries for several minutes after I disconnected the network. Let me know if there\'s anything else I can do to help troubleshoot."'
SignalR	1495	closed	4	davidfowl	2013-02-06 23:29:16	81.68			+1	b'b" Ah hah, that\'s because you\'re using long polling. Long polling doesn\'t have the client side keep alive check and it can take several minutes for the browser itself to realize that the connection is _really_ dead. Long polling is the only transport where we expect this behavior (since it\'s the default browser behavior).  Another thing you can do is turn on the server side tracing and reproduce the problem again and show what\'s in the log file.  This gist shows how to turn on tracing for all transports: url  All output goes into a  at the root (you can change this).  Run the repro again and show the server side log (keeping track of the specific connection id you\'re interested in, you can get it from $). There\'s a bug today that we have in RC2 that\'s fixed in RTW where a longpolling connection can timeout and it will never fire disconnect. Adding that server side tracing should reveal if that\'s the issue you\'re seeing."'
SignalR	1495	closed	5	davidfowl	2013-02-06 23:29:16	31.22		+1		b"b' This is the change that was made in 1.0 RTW url '

b'b" We are trying to use SignalR out of the web context as a  mechanism for real time ticking market data from within Excel. When a user opens a sheet
column11: a custom Excel RTD addin (the signal R client) subscribes to all market data streams in the cells on the server (the signalR hub; Currently a Windows Service). After implementing SignalR we found that not all requests were getting from the client to the hub in our example sheet (around 2000 requests). _: The underlying connection was closed: A connection that was expected to be kept alive was closed by the server. -This example is an oversimplification of the issue but seems to consistently reproduce the error.  This error also seems to occur on broadcast back to the clients. url  It feels like I\'m doing something fundamentally wrong does anyone have any input on this issue? Thanks."'

column11: e.g. if time issue cause CheckForMessages() getting called by Receive(object state)  before _() in SetupQueryNotification()
column12: then _() in SetupQueryNotification() will  because _ set to different one and it is not open. In this case SqlDependency become stop working. So in SetupQueryNotification() it is more robust to call CheckForMessages() instead of ProcessReader(_())

column10: b"b' @DamianEdwards do you have any idea why ServiceBroker being on or off would affect this behavior?'"

b'b" It shouldn\'t have any bearing other than possibly taking a bit longer to recover as the SQL notification often goes stale if it was already established when an error occurs and eventually times out (60 seconds). Whereas the retry loop just keeps on truckin\' until it works again. The extra time involved (depending on the send rate) could mean you hit a queue or message buffer limit somewhere
column11: but I thought they were pretty high."'

column10: b'b\' @sandhyak SignalR connections end in one of two ways: clean and unclean. A clean disconnect happens when the client explicitly calls stop() or the browser window is closed (in which case we call stop() on your behalf). The call to stop() actually sends a request to the server to inform it that the client is going away. In this case
column11: we can raise OnDisconnected immediately. An unclean disconnect happens when the client can\\\'t send that "abort" request
column12: or simply goes away due to network conditions (like you\\\'re explaining here). In that case
column13: the server can only know the client is gone when the HTTP request last associated with that client is no longer there. This can take anywhere from 0 seconds (immediate) to many minutes
column14: depending on the network layers between client and server. Once this happens
column15: the server raises OnDisconnected once the DisconnectTimeout threshold has been reached (~30 seconds by default).\''

column11: when call UseServiceBus at app_start
column12: if it returns error like time out on init connection to ServiceBus

column10: b'b" Do you know what transport you\'re using?"'
b"b' When I change the code to skip websockets it seems to just hang:  '"
b'b" OK found the issue. Not a bug in SignalR
column11: it\'s a bug in your application (a _VERY_ subtle one at that). You can\'t use session with SignalR (it\'ll make this problem happen). When you use Session
column12: serializes requests (runs them one at a time) and that breaks all concurrency in SignalR. To disable session remove Session_Start and Session_End from your MvcApplication.  "'

column10: b'b\' Believe it was picking up SSE as transport before. Weird. Okay
column11: thanks. Not sure I\\\'d consider using a Session event a "bug" in the app but a few things then:Why doesn\\\'t 1.1.2 exhibit this behavior? The session events are present with it and it worked fine thereThat\\\'s extremely subtle and was the result of hours of head scratching. If it isn\\\'t compatible with any form of session use
column12: maybe that should be in the  when the nuget package is installed as well as any wiki documentation later?Events from server to client seem to fire fine with the session event.We\\\'re not currently storing anything in Session state anymore but I could see a scenario or two where that could be useful later. Suggested workarounds for session state or similar with SignalR?\''

column10: b'b" I see the exact same behavior on 1.1.2 when I tried in your sample. Requests are blocked behind other requests because of the session lock in . Fiddler shows this clearly.Sure we\'ll update or docs. It doesn\'t happen in websockets since it doesn\'t support session.Use a database or cache or anything else other than session."'
b'b" Hmm that\'s weird because it worked fine for me with the session events on 1.1.2 but it\'s a moot point currently. Thanks again"'
b'b" Ok we\'re fixing this bug. Turns out it\'s a pretty complicated change in how SignalR runs as part of the  pipeline. The MVC pipeline is turning on session when we don\'t want it."'
b"b' Cool
column11: thanks'"

b"b' JS Client Always check for valid reconnect window before making a request in clients'"

b"b' Before the client makes any request (after connecting) it should always check to ensure that the time since the server was last heard from (the last successful result from the server) is less than the configured disconnect threshold. This is in addition to the keep alive check that runs in forever transports. It helps address scenarios where the client makes requests although the server has already disconnect them
column11: e.g. when a browser is suspended on a mobile device.'"

column14: Serversent events and polling. I also replicate same in win 2008/IIS 7 / .Net 4. I believe this is a bug in the SignalR . I would highly appreciate your help. Regards

column10: b'b" And you can\'t reproduce the same behavior in a new application?"'
b'b" I finally found the root issue.  I used a custom IHubDescriptorProvider to list all my HubDescriptor that rely on . With  WebSocket protocol
column11: is null inside HubdDescriptorProvider whereas with ServerSentEvent protocol
column12: is not null. To correct my issue I have to change my HubDescriptorProvider implementation to not rely on .  As a conclusion : the intial error seems to be related to the difference between net40 and net45. In fact it was becausenet40 version use ServerSentEvent Protocol by defaultnet45 version use WebSocket Protocol by default and my application didn\'t fully support WebSocket protocol. Thanks for your help. "'

column10: b'b" Just FYI
column11: we saw this every time with the service bus scaleout implementation and finally
column12: as a workaround
column13: added some startup code to fire a message through each stream just to prime things. It seemed like it was an issue with the internal subscriptions being done on a queued work pool thread and that thread not executing before the first message came in
column14: although we didn\'t verify that 100%. But it was always reproducible for us
column15: in a local IIS instance or on Azure."'

column10: b"b' SignalR 2.0 Death Spiral with 80 Clients'"
b'b\' ProblemOur SignalR system has a tendency to go into a death spiral.  If the SignalR project hosted in IIS gets busy enough for a short interval
column11: the RAM usage and CPU usage will explode into a point of no return.  And even if the CPU does level out
column12: the RAM is never
column13: ever freed which makes it easier to spiral on the next spike. Environment1 publicly exposed IIS hosted machine answering client requests over a hub2 private OWIN self hosted NServiceBuses that process data and publish deltas The NServiceBus machines publish over a Redis scaleout backplane.  No clients connect directly to them.  The IIS machine will answer requests like "Get my configuration"
column14: Answer my heartbeat
column15:
What should I display since I just started up?" in addition to taking subscriptions by adding connections to groups. ReproOnce we have about 70-80 client machines connected the IIS server is stable @ 200 MB RAM, and < 1-2% cpu.  I can use a testing webpage with a simple javascript for loop which is guaranteed to start the death spiral. The function it calls is defined as follows; This _FlatScreenHubService is a singleton object and JsonHelper is just a helper object for serialization that is used for all server responses to the client.  All we\\\'re doing is returning a datetime we use to estimate the server\\\'s clock time compared to the client\\\'s clock. The JsonHelper is defined as follows; More thoughts on ReproDuring the business day it\\\'s not even necessary to abuse the heartbeat function.  Once enough clients have a hiccup, the chain of reconnection calls will be enough to start a death spiral and that\\\'s the point of no return.  Out of 6644 function calls, 6643 during a 1 hour period finished in less than 170 ms.  95% finish in less than 1 ms.  Based on what we\\\'ve seen in publications, there is no way this kind of load should cause a death spiral like this.  So we are puzzled if we\\\'re just doing something structurally wrong.\''
SignalR	2899	closed	1	dstrickland67	2014-02-21 14:53:14	409.2		+1		b'b\' I think I found a critical piece of the death spiral, i.e. how to prevent part of the memory leak. I found a post talking about how unhandled exceptions in the TaskScheduler can cause very critical things to explode.  So once I added a handler and marked the exceptions as "observed" we would still see memory spikes, however the memory usage would in fact go down when the CPU evened out.  This makes the system harder to spike. However there is still a lot of strain on the server when it boots while 60 clients are trying to reconnect, and that\\\'s still not acceptable.  I am tinkering with more settings like these;  \''
SignalR	2899	closed	2	davidfowl	2014-02-21 14:53:14	734.22	+1			b'b" First thing you should do is not change any of those settings. If anything, increasing those values will bring more pain since you\'ll be holding onto things longer in memory (tweaking disconnect timeout without understanding the implication is dangerous). I\'m not fully understanding the scenario. If anything maybe there\'s an issue with the redis backplane? Are you in a server farm?"'
SignalR	2899	closed	3	nmehlei	2014-02-21 14:53:14	332.2		+1		b"b' How is persistence configured in redis? Those could affect performance dramatically'

I will inquire and see if I can post a copy of the redis config for both. I will post more information as I get more data from testing this weekend.  I am no longer able to reproduce the death spiral on demand by spamming it with heartbeats
column14: but I have seen a couple spirals today which have no obvious cause as of yet. More details to follow!"'

column10: b"b' Closing this out due to lack of detail. Add a comment if you have more information.'"

b"b' After a little more search and refactoring.  We have moved all data fetches to a MVC api controller. We created a signalr multi-threaded test client which just spins up connections and waits.  No notifications are being pushed pushed thru signalr. If we spin up 500 1.5k connections to the signalr server and then terminate the load tester
column11: the signalr server go up by 200 MB in about 60 seconds after the clients terminate and never comes back down and CPU spikes (on the two core server)  for 2-5 minutes.  If you repeat this same sequence
column12: it continues to grow each and every time.  Even hours after the spikes
column13: the process memory never shrinks. If you then start the test client (load test) and spin up another 500 + connections and then terminate the load test
column14: the server spikes again until eventually the process exhausts the server memory. However
column15: if the connections slowly fall off (about 100 / minute) until there are no connections
column16: there is no memory spike or cpu spike.  You can do this many times in a row with zero issues.  Seems as though the breaking point is about 500 connections that die at the same time.'"

column10: b'b" @MDL-ACarlson It looks like there are a few things going on in this reproduction. The short answer is that I suggest upgrading from version 2.0.2 of SignalR to 2.0.3
column11: removing the custom buffer size
column12: and looking into the possibility of using Crank for testing your application. The issue seems to only reproduce when redis is enabled using SignalR 2.0.2 as it is in the sample projects. For my reproduction
column13: I was running both client and server on the same system and there were issues with the  starving the SignalRTest application. The actual memory leak appears to be a result of the interaction between the older version of SignalR and redis under this high stress situation. In the  the DefaultMessageBufferSize is set to 25 and that seems a bit strange. In most cases
column14: you shouldn\'t need to customize the SignalR connection and buffering settings. After reworking the LoadTest a bit to cut down on the number of threads it was consuming
column15: I observed SignalRTest managing around 5000 clients without issues. This was primarily the result of making the return type of SpawnClients (and the methods it calls) into async Tasks and replacing the .Wait() calls with awaits. Load testing a SignalR application can be quite tricky and
column16: if possible
column17: I suggest looking into using the Crank () project that is included in the SignalR source."'

column10: b'b" What is the expected behaviour if message bus tries to write more messages to SqlScaleout than the database server can handle? Problem is
column11: if we send 1 message / sec on the message bus
column12: but if there are let\'s say 50 longpolling clients listening
column13: then this raises our message bus messages / sec to over 50 messages / sec because everytime a longpolling client creates a new /poll request (which is triggered by the 1) a message like this is sent to Scaleout for each of the listening longpolling clients: which scales pretty badly. Is this by design? sorry
column14: misclicked and  the issue."'

column10: b'b" @thomaswr ah you\'re correct. This is ultimately a design flaw in SignalR. We\'re attempting to mask too much of the nature of distributed connections that move from one machine to another. We\'re looking at removing this behavior now in the next release (#2996) and adding other API to help address the problem of tracking when users disconnect from your application. This will effectively mean the disconnect event simply represents a single server\'s view of a connection disconnecting
column11: not necessarily the connection leaving altogether."'

column10: b"b' @DamianEdwards Thanks for the update. Is it feasible to backport this to 1.x?This is one of the major factors for our scalability problems'"
b'b" @thomaswr we\'ll look at backporting this  we have a fix. Can you share how many web-servers you have in your farm where you\'re seeing this issue?"'
b'b" Great news!Sure. It\'s already in my first post: 8 webservers."'
b'b" Thanks for the info. Have you adjusted the connection pool settings at all? If not
column11: I believe the defaults are 50 connections per connection pool
column12: meaning in worst case scenario
column13: you could be hitting your SQL Server with 400 concurrent operations
column14: which might well be enough to cause it issues. You could try adjusting the connection pool size for the connection string you\'ve configured SignalR to use and see if that helps relieve the pressure on the SQL Server
column15: although note it will obviously mean SignalR operations will be blocked more often
column16: but parts of your app using the other connection string might be less effected. Right now
column17: Long Polling just isn\'t a good fit in your set up. We\'re working on the changes."'

column10: b'b" Reducing the max pool size sounds reasonable
column11: I\'ll try that. Thanks. FYI
column12: there is another issue amplifying the Long Polling issue for us. Mobile data providers tend to cripple SSE connects which leads to a lot more Long Polling clients than browser statistics would suggest. I wrote about this here (#1667). I can supply wireshark logs if needed."'

column10: b"b' @DamianEdwards Is there any possible workaround for this
column11: besides disabling LongPolling for our users? Thanks.'"

column10: b"b' @thomaswr not that I can think of
column11: no.'"

b"b' Little documentation on SqlServer Scaleout'"

b"b' Documentation about SqlServer Scaleout is very scarce. There are some open questions like the following.What does the _TableCount_ setting do exactly? How to find the proper value for an application?  The info we have is:  What are the reasons for and against enabling _MaxQueueLength_ setting? The info we have is:  More information about the meaning and correlation of performance counters'"
b'b\' Thanks for the feedback. TableCount changes how many tables messages are sharded across. Our scale-out providers support the concept of "streams" as units of scale
column11: where each stream ensures ordered . This requirement generally means a stream is a potential scale bottleneck
column12: so we support multiple streams to help reduce that bottleneck. If multiple streams are configured
column13: we\\\'ll automatically distribute (shard) messages across these streams in a way that ensures messages sent from any given connection are in order. In the case of SQL Server
column14: each table is a logical stream. More tables means (in theory) more concurrent writes can take place
column15: but as always you need to test and tune for your application. The MaxQueueLength setting controls the length of the scale-out send queue. Setting it to a value above 0 will place all messages in a send queue to be sent one at a time to the configured messaging backplane. If the size of the queue goes above the configured length
column16: subsequent calls to send will fail immediately until the queue is lower than the setting again. It\\\'s off by default because the implemented backplanes generally have their own -control in place. In the case of SQL Server
column17: connection pooling effectively limits the number of sends going on at any one time. The counters are detailed at url  Is there any more information you think this document needs? We\\\'ll update the docs with this information.\''

column10: b'b" Thank you for the clarification.Is it okay to give feedback on documentation as it arises? It\'s very detailed and helpful mostly."'
b"b' Absolutely :smile: '"

b'b\' Adding the following to the Performance doc (and links to this section from the SQL and Service Bus docs): Each stream ensures ordered read and write operations; a single stream is a potential scale bottleneck
column11: so the number of streams can be increased to help reduce that bottleneck. If multiple streams are used
column12: SignalR will automatically distribute (shard) messages across these streams in a way that ensures messages sent from any given connection are in order. The MaxQueueLength setting controls the length of the scaleout send queue maintained by SignalR. Setting it to a value above 0 will place all messages in a send queue to be sent one at a time to the configured messaging backplane. If the size of the queue goes above the configured length
column13: subsequent calls to send will fail immediately with an InvalidOperationException until the queue is lower than the setting again. Queueing is disabled by default because the implemented backplanes generally have their own queuing or flow-control in place. In the case of SQL Server
column14: connection pooling effectively limits the number of sends going on at any one time. By default
column15: only one stream is used
column16: and queueing is disabled
column17: but these settings can be changed through configuration on SQL Server and Service Bus: .NET Server Code for configuring table count and queue length for SQL Server backplane var connectionString = "(your connection string)";var config = new SqlScaleoutConfiguration(connectionString) {   TableCount = 3
column18: MaxQueueLength = 50 };(config);.NET Server Code for configuring topic count and queue length for Service Bus backplane string connectionString = "Service Bus connection string";var config = new ServiceBusScaleoutConfiguration(connectionString
column19:
YourAppName") {   TopicCount = 3,  MaxQueueLength = 50 };(config);\''

b"b' Fixed in 83726e069c2c19a32a2e57a990facad17328906b'"
b'b" Rework the .NET client\'s TransportAbortHandler"'
b'b" Unlike on the JS client
column11: the .NET client waits to receive a message before completes (or waits 30 seconds if a message isn\'t received). I don\'t really see the purpose behind this
column12: and I think this add unnecessary complication to the .NET client. One minor bug was introduced by this with the introduction of long-polling keep-alives. Now that can be called by the
column13: the current poll request can be aborted without stopping the connection. This aborted request will in turn trigger which means that when is called afterwards will complete immediately instead of after receiving a message as intended. I think we should consider not waiting to receive a message before completing  ."'

column10: b"b' Fixed in 7358f1d'"

b"b' We had to revert the change since it introduced a couple of issues and races we were able to identify and possibly some we have not hit. It became apparent that the change is too risky. We will need to re-think the transport-connection interaction to fix this correctly  make the Stop call async.'"
b'b" We\'ll look at this in v3"'

I saw url  and maybe the fix for the .net client is not applied to the SIlverlight client? Stop code which takes 30 seconds this is not called from within an On method..  '"
b'b" Thanks
column11: we\'ll take a look. If you can share any more information that may help us to reproduce the issue please do so."'

column10: b"b' Even though we send Abort request it is actually never sent by the HttpClient when using the portable HttpClient library. The 30 seconds is the default timeout we wait for the response to the Abort request. Until I find out why the underlying HttpClient never sends the Abort request you can use the overload and provide a smaller timeout.'"

b"b' It looks that even though the SignalR client invokes the request is actually never sent to the server. I tracked it down to the method which calls (see the stack trace below) but the callback (which in this case is the  ) is never invoked. Since from what I could see the is responsible for sending the request the request is never sent and the method is blocked infinitely waiting for the callback to complete. '"

b"b' This is because of a deadlock. We block the thread waiting for the response to the abort request to the server. If the thread we are blocking happens to be the UI thread it will cause a dead lock since Silverlight wants to send the request on the UI thread.'"

b"b' @yowl one way to work around this issue is to invoke .Stop on a non-UI thread e.g.: another workaround would be to set the Stop timeout to 0  like this: note that in this case the abort request will never be sent to the server.'"
b'b\' Fixing #3067 will "fix" this issue.\''
b'b\' "Fixed" in 7358f1d we no longer block to receive a response to abort request.\''

b"b' We had to revert the change since it introduced a couple of issues and races we were able to identify and possibly some we have not hit. It became apparent that the change is too risky. We will need to re-think the transport-connection interaction to fix this correctly  make the Stop call async.'"
b'b" We\'ll look at this for v3"'

column11: hence the "end-of-file" error. As an example
column12: see url  (though it could be something else causing the issue on your machine).\''

column10: b"b' Scaleout can miss messages if backplane message is missed and next message received moves to next fragment'"

b'b" Consider the case where an configured for scaleout misses a  backplane message (id=100). The next message comes in (id=101) and is stored in but the add goes into a new fragment. Now somebody asks for all messages since 100
column11: which doesn\'t exist in any fragment (it\'s in between two fragments). e.g. [ 95
column15: 99 ] _Missed message 100_ [ 101
column19: 105 ] In this case the store should return all messages after 100 (101 to 105) but instead treats the caller as up to date."'

b"b' Server to client message ordering NOT preserved'"
b'b\'  does not preserve ordering of messages sent from server to client... Will always return 0
column14: 4 in NON-SQL-scaleout scenarios
column15: but will often return out of order when using (new SqlScaleoutConfiguration("...")) Using SSE or websockets makes no difference.Using 1 or 10 webservers makes no difference.Using sql server 2005 or sql server 2014 makes no difference.\''

column10: b'b" To preserve ordering with a scaleout IMessageBus
column11: you need to [await your client invocations]url  For example: If you do this
column12: ordering will be preserved. While this isn\'t strictly necessary when you are using the default in-memory IMessageBus (since a completed Task will always be returned in this scenario)
column13: it is still best practice in case the IMessageBus implementation changes. Unfortunately
column14: this can be a real gotcha since client invocations are dynamic meaning Intellisense will not indicate that the invocation returns a Task."'

column11: most of our code samples do not use await when calling  . Even though most of our samples do not rely on sequentially executing client methods
column12: we should probably use await anyway just to make people extra aware that these calls are indeed awaitable. I am reopening the issue and adding the "documentation" tag.\''

b'b\' In case a project has a lot of hubs
column11: fails with "query string is too long". It is because names of all hubs are sent via GET request in query string: Suggestion: What about to send connectionData in body of POST request?Question: How to use SignalR in projects with many \\\'hub\\\' classes? Is possible to tweak SignalR not to send all hub names?\''

column10: b'b" The suggestion of making /negotiate a POST request and putting connectionData in the body sounds reasonable as long as JSONP isn\'t required. If you are not actually using all the hubs in your app from each client
column11: you could avoid sending all the hub names by not setting up callbacks (e.g.  ) for the hubs you are not using."'

column11: in my case each hub represents a repository (with change notification) for entity of a type. I have many types of entities. Is it possible to register new hubs during the connected session? (I cannot easily restart the connection each time I need to add a hub
column12: since some async method calls of other hubs may have being pending in the meantime.)'"

column10: b'b\' If you want to listen to callbacks from a given Hub
column11: you need to have at least one callback set up for that Hub when you start the connection. You can use []url  to add additional callbacks to a Hub you are already subscribed to after you start the connection
column12: but you cannot add callbacks for a Hub you weren\\\'t initially subscribed to when you called start. Here is a relevant "note" from the linked guide:\''

column13: I have my own (one direction communication) infrastructure: each webrole instance creates a new subscription for itself for each topic inside a service bus namespace and creates a new route for signalr for each topic. I post messages only directly to the topic. SignalR clients don\'t send messages back. When a user connects
column14: I put him to a group
column15: where the group name equals with the topic name. When a message received from a topic I forward it to the signalr group which name equals the topic name. So it\'s a must have to put the user to the correct group during the OnConnected event.  Based on my resarch this issue is an old issue and it was fixed in the latest realase

column10: b'b\' I was able to narrow down the problem
column11: and it was turned out
column12: that the root of the problem is an invalid connection state. If there is no backplane
column13: but you have multiple nodes behind a cloudapp hostname
column14: it can happen
column15: that a client connection (onConnect() or onReconnect() events) occures one node
column16: but the messages travel across another node (I mean the server side OnReceived() occures on a different node). In the example below the client is connected to the node called "SignalingWebRole_IN_0". The Send button has a simple functionality: the OnClick event sends a message to SignalR server
column17: which broadcasts the message back to all of the clients. As you can see on the picture the client message was received and broadcasted by "SignalingWebRole_IN_1"
column18: however this client is connected to node 0. In case of a normal connection
column19: the message should be received on the same node where the OnConnected() event has occured: SignalingWebRole_IN_0.![image]url \''

column10: b'b\' Configuring the load balancer from the default settings (5-tuple) to 2-tuple mode solves the problem. To do that
column11: the loadBalancerDistribution tag inside the Endpoint section of the WorkerRole should be modified to "sourceIP". This parameter is located in the  file. Example: Check url  for details.  Thanks the help for Attila Ersek and Balint Farkas.\''

b'b\' @UshaV-Questionmark @Joe-U-Questionmark Sorry for the delayed response. Unfortunately
column11: I am unable to reproduce this issue. I tried reproing this by running our [raw connection sample app]url  on IIS. I then connected with multiple clients using WebSockets
column12: and unplugged the network cable from one of the clients. I then observed the connection events from the still-connected clients. I see the following output in messages (I did this about 3 times and consistently saw the same results):"7/27/2015 12:52:46 PM: f154941d-daf0-459e-b082-2eeb1911f0e7 joined from [IP Address]""7/27/2015 12:53:33 PM: f154941d-daf0-459e-b082-2eeb1911f0e7 disconnected uncleanly" This is the expected behavior. It should take a little over 40 seconds by default for an unclean disconnect to fire. The main reason it takes this long is to give the client a smallish window where it can reconnect. The fact that you don\\\'t see return false until 17 minutes after the web socket disconnects implies that the [ callback]url  is firing 17 minutes too late. Can you determine which [  implementation]url  is being used? or  ? Are you running SignalR on IIS? Also
column13: are you able to repro this issue on a LAN? I\\\'m wondering if some sort of proxy might be causing issues. Maybe we could try setting to false when the last write fails like we do for [other transports]url  A failed write should always occur if the client disconnects since SignalR sends a keep alive every 10 seconds by default. Is there any reason we aren\\\'t doing this @davidfowl?\''

column10: b'b" I\'ve also been involved in looking at this issue with @UshaV-Questionmark and @Joe-U-Questionmark  It appears to me that
column11: by design
column12: SignalR servers don\'t know if the client is dead or not and they rely on notification from the underlying websocket for connection failures i.e.
column13: the OnClose callback.  (The same is not true the other way around of course as the server can be configured to send keep-alive messages to the client periodically so that the client always knows if it is connected.) Sadly
column14: you can\'t just expect a write failure from a websocket as an indication of a broken connection (it may remain buffered somewhere).  Different  topologies are likely to behave differently. Websockets don\'t automatically monitor the underlying connection status either.  IMO
column15: the only reliable way is to issue ping requests from the server and check for pong responses from the client.  AFAICT SignalR is not doing  those message types don\'t appear to have been exposed by the underlying websocket API. As a result
column16: the best solution I can suggest is to configure IIS websockets to do the  for you.  This ensures that your connection will close if it breaks unexpectedly.  I found the following SO answer useful in this respect:url  Early testing suggests this has resolved our problem."'

column10: b'b" It\'s great to hear that it looks like you\'ve resolved this problem by enabling WebSocket  in IIS. I did not know about this configuration setting previously. I made sure to upvote the answer on SO. @Rick-Anderson Do you think we could add this to our [troubleshooting docs]url  Thanks for reporting back with the fix."'
b'b" @halter73 @swl10  good idea
column11: I\'ll get that added."'

column10: b'b\' We are trying to determine the optimal value for "pingInterval". We found that it is somehow related to KeepAlive setting of SignalR. We are not getting ping requests if "pingInterval" value is more than KeepAlive value which by default 10 seconds.  Could you please tell us what is the relationship between these two settings "pingInterval" and "KeepAlive"?\''

b'b\' SignalR\\\'s "pingInterval" has no relation to WebSocket  or "KeepAlive". The pingInterval configures how how often SignalR sends an Ajax GET request (usually to /) so cookies get refreshed. I go into more detail on SO: url \''
b'b" I think there is a misunderstanding here
column11: the pingInterval here means the IIS websocket pingInterval.  On the wire we see an empty text frame \'\\\\x81\\\\x02{}\' received every 10s from the server which I assume is the websocket keep alive implemented at the SignalR level.  If we set IIS\'s pingInterval to 5s we receive ping frames \'\\\\x89\\\\x04ping\' from IIS but if we set it to
column12: say
column13: 15s we do not see any ping frames and the problem with the failure to detect broken sessions returns.  It looks like IIS is only sending ping frames when the connection has been idle for the pingInterval
column14: we\'re wondering if anyone can confirm that.  If this is the case
column15: then SignalR\'s keep alive frames are scuppering the detection of failed clients and we should recommend that SignalR\'s websocket keep-alive is always larger than the IIS websocket pingInterval if prompt handling of unclean client disconnect is important.  FYI
column16: it appears that IIS will close the connection fairly quickly (within 10s) if it\'s ping frame is not responded to with a pong."'

column11: in practice
column12: the fix only works if you pick pingInterval carefully. '"

b'b\' @Joe-U-Questionmark Can you provide a bit more detail on what you\\\'re still encountering and if the IIS configuration was able to resolve your issue (as @davidfowl asked)? I\\\'d like to try and get the bottom of this but need to understand your scenario a little better to do so :). This is the expected behavior. The ping frames are designed to "keep the connection alive" so are only sent if no other message was sent along the wire. As far as I know
column11: this shouldn\\\'t be the case. The only detection we have in SignalR is the TCP connection timing out at the OS level due to unacknowledged writes
column12: so even SignalR\\\'s ping frames should be able to produce that result.\''

b"b' /start requests never time out '"

b'b\' We have disabled websockets in production as we had reports from users from large companies with secure proxies that after making a few websocket connections (as they navigated from page to page on a SignalR enabled site) that the Websocket connection and every web request in general were failing (disabling websockets solved the problem) The actual issue was that /Start requests never time out:The last message our users got in the console was "SignalR: webSockets transport connected. Initiating start request."The http ajax request to "/?transport=webSockets" from the function (lines 1435 & 1154) does not have a timeout (as AjaxDefaults has timeout set to null on line 66). As all the requests in the proxy have been exhausted the "/?transport=webSockets" request never responds and as there is no timeout the page hangs at this point.  \\xc2\\xa0  If SignalR had a sensible timeout for the "/?transport=webSockets" request
column11: closed the failed websocket and fell back to the another protocol this would likely have recovered the situation. Reproduction stepsCreate a Hub with an OnConnected method that never completes.Try to connect to the Hub with the JavaScript.\''

column10: b'b" This would be a new set of timeouts that we don\'t have today
column11: so it would have to be disabled by default. Today
column12: neither or have timeouts because they are directly mapped to user code executing on the server. We don\'t know how long that will take
column13: so we can\'t introduce a timeout by default now as it would be a breaking change
column14: since user code is executing subject to that timeout.  As a workaround
column15: you can timeout or hub invocations yourself by simply running your own timer using and calling when it elapses.  "'

column10: b"b' I suggest you either implement the timeout with a large default value (anything is better than nothing!) or provide some sample code either here or in the docs
column11: otherwise prepare for 100s of bad implementations. '"

column11: this isn\'t related to an incomplete task but rather a proxy that is hanging requests in certain situations. The incomplete task is simply a way to reproduce the same behavior."'

b"b' Remote stack trace is lost on client during deserialization'"

b'b\' I\\\'m trying to log SignalR remote stack trace exception in test\\\'s output. Initially it was looking promising  property allows serialize it to wire. Unfortunately it didn\\\'t work. Further investigations shown that HubDispatcher writes stack trace into HubResponse and then it is serialized into transport. On the client side initially response is treated as string or as JObject. Then it is deserialized into HubResponse\\\'s counterpart HubResult. Let\\\'s compare them: As you can see  is serialized as "T" json property and deserialized into... / ! The only hope I had is that stack trace can be processed before response is deserialized into HubResponse
column11: while working with raw . Unfortunately I was unable to find any traces of such behavior\''

b"b' @DmitryNaumov I guess the question is what would you do with the stack trace when you have it and why is it helpful and safe to pass it to the application itself? For diagnostic purposes it will be logged as per the quote above.'"
b'b" @moozzyk As far as I can remember
column11: it was quite a while ago
column12: I need remote stack trace to put it into exception which will be stored in InnerException of our application one. Later whole exception hierarchy will be catched by app\'s exception handler and logged as a whole into our log sink. This is very useful for our CI
column13: when I see client scenarios failing due to error on server
column14: but it takes time to find out root cause exception in server logs."'

column10: b"b' When the connectionstring contains a channelPrefix
column11: the redis key and pubsub messages do not match anymore. This breaks all SignalR connections with the following trace:### transports  ### bus  ### Minimal repro steps1. Enable redis scale out in the samples app2. add any channelPrefix to the connectionstring e.g.  ### Expected result Everything is working fine clients can connect. All keys in redis may start with the channelPrefix
column12: or the mapping between PUBSUB messages an the corresponding key should respect the configured channelPrefix.### Actual result All connections are immediately closed by the server. The client tries to fallback to other protocols and finally aborts the connection.### Workaround1. parse the redis connectionstring2. if it contains a channelPrefix
column13: prefix the eventKey with the channelPrefix from the connectionstring3. remove the channelPrefix from the connectionstring4. use the modified connectionstring and eventKey'"

b"b' Fix compatibility with '"

b'b" This PR addresses a very specific issue we\'re having while running SignalR on top of  Core using . We\'re aware this is an unsupported setup and it\'s part of our migration path going forward.  Running SignalR on Core actually works when addressing 2 separate issues. The first one is not setting
column11: which is easily fixed with some middleware gymnastics.  The second issue is core\'s owin bridge does not expose a and causes SignalR to fall back to using  . However  \'s implementation is incomplete and causes it to fail only moments later when SignalR calls  .  Fixing this second issue would be rather involved. Rather we opted to take advantage of setting the instance on the OWIN environment directly
column12: thus accomplishing the same behavior that would have provided.  With custom Middleware on our end
column13: and this fix on SignalR\'s end
column14: SignalR behaves entirely as expected on  Core in our testing. "'

column10: b'b" First off

column12: SignalR will only operate correctly in a 1-node configuration. So
column13: if you plan to scale

column15: let\'s try to dive in to that. This seems very odd to me. If messages are being broadcasted
column16: then OnConnected should have fired somewhere. Can you collect a [Fiddler]url  network trace for a single client connection? What I\'m looking for is the query string value in all the SignalR requests. When you connect to SignalR that value should contain the list of Hubs you are connected to. We\'ll only fire for the hubs listed in that data. The code you posted looks correct (you\'re subscribing to an event and doing so **before** starting) so I think that should be working
